title: The
json_encode
c
a
http://php.net/manual/en/function.json-encode.php
function will convert a PHP array (or, since PHP 5.4, an object which implements the
JsonSerializable
c
interface) to a JSON-encoded string. It returns a JSON-encoded string on success or FALSE on failure.

inline_content.Text: function will convert a PHP array (or, since PHP 5.4, an object which implements the
interface) to a JSON-encoded string. It returns a JSON-encoded string on success or FALSE on failure.

title: During encoding, the PHP data types string, integer, and boolean are converted to their JSON equivalent. Associative arrays are encoded as JSON objects, and – when called with default arguments – indexed arrays are encoded as JSON arrays. (Unless the array keys are not a continuous numeric sequence starting from 0, in which case the array will be encoded as a JSON object.)

inline_content.Text: During encoding, the PHP data types string, integer, and boolean are converted to their JSON equivalent. Associative arrays are encoded as JSON objects, and – when called with default arguments – indexed arrays are encoded as JSON arrays. (Unless the array keys are not a continuous numeric sequence starting from 0, in which case the array will be encoded as a JSON object.)

title: When used with
JSON_UNESCAPED_UNICODE
c
, reverts to the behaviour of older PHP versions, and
does not
i
escape the characters U+2028 LINE SEPARATOR and U+2029 PARAGRAPH SEPARATOR. Although valid in JSON, these characters are not valid in JavaScript, so the default behaviour of

c
was changed in version 7.1.
